item.title: Docker Cheatsheet
item.description: Docker Cheatsheet – Developer & DevOps Reference This page provides a concise, command-focused reference for common Docker tasks used by developers and DevOps engineers.

item.title: 0. Course Overview and Index
item.description: This course builds a practical mental model of Docker from first principles and then connects it to real-world DevOps workflows.

item.title: 1. Docker Images
item.description: If containers are lightweight processes, images are the immutable blueprints that define what those processes look like at runtime.

item.title: 10. Debugging Docker
item.description: When something breaks in Docker, resist the urge to “try random commands until it works.” Containers are just Linux processes with extra plumbing, so you debug them the same way: check if they exist, if they run, what they log, what they listen on, and what they can reach.

item.title: 11. From Docker to Orchestrators
item.description: All the mental models you’ve built (images, containers, networks, volumes, Compose) are the foundation of Swarm and Kubernetes.

item.title: 2. Docker Containers
item.description: Most people start by thinking of containers as “lightweight VMs.” That mental model works for a few days, then hurts you for years.

item.title: 3. Docker Networking
item.description: Docker networking feels magical until something doesn’t connect—then it feels like black magic.

item.title: 4. Docker Volumes
item.description: Containers are designed to be disposable. That’s perfect for stateless services, but terrible for things like databases, uploads, and logs.

item.title: 5. Dockerfile Mastery
item.description: A Dockerfile is not a shell script; it’s a deterministic build recipe that produces an immutable image.

item.title: 6. Multi‑Stage Docker Builds
item.description: Multi‑stage builds exist to solve a very concrete problem: images that are huge, slow to ship, and full of compilers and dev tools that have no business being in production.
